author: 993andme
body:
I see your point in general, and I agree with it in concept…but man pets.com and I have enough of a history that I feel i can say that they and are nothing alike.

I worked at Microsoft in the product group back in the 90s, and talked to someone at pets.com seemingly weekly about their various needs and plans and demands. I’ll save you the boredom, but it was one horrible company with a marketing department so impressive that they had us all seeing a silly puppet at night while we slept.

Pets.com got everything right except the part where you put together a properly run management and logistics team to keep costs from killing you while you’re out spending every last penny on marketing. Pets burned their candle at both ends: losing money on just about every single thing they sold without the benefit of free advertising and hype from social media creators. Rivian was much smarter about this bit. They aren’r streaming millions of dollars a week sponsoring the rose bowl or some shit.

Instead, Rivian has been controlling costs; auto manufacturing is it’s just an unbelievably high up front capital business. Thing is though: they’ve got 4-5 years of cash on hand. Pets had 4-5 minutes, tops. Rivian partnered with one tech firm and one auto manufacturer to keep the number of roosters in the henhouse to a minimum. Pets.com took in money from anyone and everyone willing, and with them, their agenda, vision, and demands. 

Is Rivian worth anything near what the stock is selling for? Absolutely not. They just aren’t the complete windbag that pets was.

Assuming that they aren’t cooking the books in a massive fraud conspiracy, I see Rivian getting a high and tight 90% amazon style correction before either recovering to reasonable levels or being gobbled up by one of the larger automakers willing to fulfill amazon’s van order, or to simply buy out the IP they’ve certainly built up.

author: NodeDotSwift
body:
You know that making ARM processors would make them commodity manufacturers with no moat, right?

Their excess margins gone from being the only suppliers of x86 processors. If x86 continues to lag ARM in lower per watt, it’s value as a proprietary architecture fades over time.

Apple is running x86 instructions on ARM as fast as native Intel laptop processors. MSFT could do same.

And on servers few care about architecture, they care about cost of performance which Graviton is way ahead in.

author: Moon_Bass_
body:
I did a quick look at their ratios and i would say yes to long term, maybe 5-10 years?

From a non financial perpsecitve and look into Nintendo as a company, their philosophy is straight forward, they make games that can be enjoyed by adults and children and are generally pretty straight forward when compared to more "mature games".

Play a Mario game from 10 years ago and it will play the same as one today with minute differences.

They have the "casual" game market on lock as well. Though steam does appear to be entering that market with their handheld console.

Right now, imo, the game industry is ready for a new player...Sony, Nintendo, and Microsoft have been big dogs for a while now; SEGA was in but after the Dreamcast tapped out (which sucks because they *could* do well these days)

If another company were to start and enter into the casual gaming arena in a way that isn't as....crappy as mobile gaming but good enough to be taken seriously, especially from the USA side, then that could cause some problems i think.

author: Michael12390
body: Let’s say Apple traded at a $10T market cap and they had net income of $600 Billion (current net income is less than $100 Billion). How much could Apple grow their net income if it became $600 Billion? 7% growth would mean they would make $42 Billion more the next year. I think that would be extremely unrealistic. Realistic net income growth for a company of that size would be maybe 2-3%. Which also means that a PE of 16 would be completely unjustified. So if we gave Apple a PE of 10 and $600 Billion in net income, that gives a market cap of $6T. And that’s if you assume the absurdly high net income of $600 Billion which is higher than Amazon, Google, Microsoft, and Apple currently combined. There will be a point when Apple is large enough that they will greatly underperform the market just because it won’t be possible for them to grow their earnings at double digits forever.

author: RumHam1
body:
Don't get me wrong, I agree that there are a lot of indicators of overvalue.  As a buy and hold investor that believes pretty strongly in indexing - I'm pretty comfortable with the SP F PE being where it is.  

I also agree some companies are priced too far into the future.  Most of those are taking a pretty significant hit at the moment.   My personal thesis is that companies with strong balance sheets will outperform in general.  Inflation FUD is hitting growth stocks right now, with an extra punishment for not having a great balance sheet.  Companies with strong balance sheets have mostly held their ground so far.  

As a buy and hold person who is big into indexing, I'm comfortable with the SP F PE of around 21.  Short term growth projections justify it IMO.  My individual picks are pretty focused around strong balance sheets and good earnings.  Only about 10% of my total is in companies with more than a 18 forward p/e (and half of that is Microsoft).

author: babydragon89
body: You have to look further why the stock didn't do well 5 years before. Back when Steve Ballmer was the CEO, he made lots of wrong decisions. One of them was Windows phone that killed of Nokia brand. He also pushed for stack ranking that made lots of talent left the company. When Satya took the control, he shifted the focus entirely on Cloud, Office, and Open Source (Github acquire). He also decided to scrap the old Microsoft Edge browser engine, and move to build the new browser on top of Chromium. This is why MSFT became the beast and keep growing steadily for the last few years.

author: paq12x
body:
Why do they do it?  Because:

It's a smart thing to do for every year.  This year is particularly special because of tax reasons.

For example, if you live in Seattle and have a bunch of shares in Microsoft, Apple, Costco, Amazon for more than a year.  If you sell those shares after this year (for a sizeable profit or you already a high earner) and if the build-back-better bill is passed as-is, your tax bill would be 7% (state, 0 for this year, has nothing to do with the bill) + 39.6% (used to be 20% for higher earners) + 3.8% (Obama care tax - same as last year - for high earners).  That's more than 50%.   If you sell them this year, it would be 23.8%.

For tax harvesting,  believing in the company alone it not enough.  You have to believe that the company would turn around in 31 days to hold the stock.  

For example.  If you bought BABA at $160 and now it's $130 and you believe that BABA will be $1000 in 2024 but not back to $160 by Jan 31, it makes sense to sell now, reduce the tax liability then buy it back after the 31 days wait period at a price somewhere between 130 and 160 (I simplified the math significantly, the exact break even price is the function of your tax rate).

For first year trader, they'll see the tax bill if there is a net profit plus the under payment penalty (if their income+profit is above $125k.  If it's below that, no penalty).  Cutting losses is a great way to avoid that penalty either by staying below the 125k cut off of just reduce the penalty in general.

For me specifically,  I have a rental property to sell (not sure yet) so I will bring some of the unrealized loss into next year (only the one that has some chance of recovering) to offset my LTC gains after tax harvesting a bunch this year.

Building wealth is strategy that involves tax avoidance as much as maximizing profit/income.   After all,  mega back door Roth, cash value life insurance, HSA, 429, regular Roth etc. are all about future/current tax avoidance.

Considering you “love” them, I’d figure you could afford *1 hour every 3 months* to get an update on the company’s performance from leadership themselves. My heart skips a beat when I read the headline about them setting the date. Sometimes listening to conference calls is a beneficial chore, but MSFT reports are like my favorite band coming to town.

author: Mike_Ropenis
body:
>about to reinvent Web 3.0 and crypto gaming.

But until they do this (if they can, which is unlikely because that is a massive pivot for a phyiscal retailer to make) they are still a mall based retailer with:

* shrinking revenue over the last 5 years
* consistent losses over the last 3 fiscal years
* no ownership of any gaming IP

And as of 2020 the industry officially passed the critical 50% threshold for games being purchased digitally. EA, one of the biggest gaming companies in the world that owns most of the major sports IPs, hit 52% in 2020 and the trend is expected to continue. GameStop has no way to get any money on any digital purchase that isn't made through their own website.

They are competing against the digital marketplaces owned by MSFT, AMZN, Sony, GOOG, and AAPL, and then in person sales they are also competing against COST, BBY,  TGT and WMT.

Chewy never turned a profit until Cohen left.

Sources:

https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/GME/

https://screenrant.com/digital-game-sales-consoles-outnumber-physical-first-time/

https://www.ign.com/articles/why-digital-sales-could-totally-dominate-physical-formats-in-just-a-few-years

https://www.polygon.com/2020/8/11/21363951/video-game-sales-digital-online-xbox-one-ps4-publisher-figures-ea-activision-2k-games

author: JGWol
body:
I think the world will scream at you from every direction in regards to how you should handle your money. Go short, go long, invest in real estate, buy gold, buy crypto, buy NFTs. Short crypto, go cash. Whatever.

Truth is no one knows what will happen. Just because tech is over valued doesn’t mean we have to have a -30% limit down. We could just see less alpha until things catch up. The only major pull back we have seen has been on meme stocks or Covid stocks that were way over valued. Like way way

It’s why even if you aren’t investing (who in WSB is) you should at least be making your gambles with underlyings that are somewhat sensible. Buying calls on a company like Microsoft with a PE of ~30 might be more reasonable.

Also btw in relation to MSFT they had a PE of 68 (double what it is today) in March 2018. 3 years later their PE is half that and trading at 3x the price. So anyone who says a company is “overvalued” needs to stop thinking in terms of just the present.

author: harrison_wintergreen
body:
VOO and QQQ are practically the same thing. look at the top 10 holdings for each ETF, and you're buying a lot of the same stocks twice. Apple, Microsoft, Nvidia, Tesla, etc. completely dominated by American large tech-leaning companies.

QQQ is also more concentrated, only 100 stocks basically in a single industry, so potentially more risk than 500+ stocks in different industries. it's had such a red-hot run the last few years, I anticipate it'll cool off eventually. 

I'd recommend VOO + VXUS (60/40 or so)

or VTI + VXUS (60/40)

or VOO + VB (small cap) + VXUS (50/25/25)

>so does it really matter how the market is right now?

potentially. the S&P 500 under-performed 1-year T-Bills from about 1968-1982, and from 2000-2012. QQQ reached a peak in 2000, crashed, and needed 13+ years to recover. the Nikkei, main Japanese index, peaked in the late 1980s and needed 30 years to recover. in all cases, there was a big bubble that crashed. so buying at the peak can be a problem. I'm not saying there's reason to panic, but the US market, as measured by the Shiller P/E ratio, is at its second-highest point in history. historically, that's a bit of a red flag. https://www.multpl.com/shiller-pe

you could offset this risk by adding a total market fund (like VTI) or a healthy chunk in small-cap stocks (small cap dominated in the 1970s and after 2000). or add a small position, maybe 10%, in something completely different by holdings and strategy -- maybe DVYE (emerging market high dividend stocks), IGRO (developed markets international that have increased dividends historically). or perhaps a value-investing option that screens out overvalued stocks (VOOV, IVLU, etc)

author: peachezandsteam
body:
The same reason people listed to the top songs on radio/streaming platforms… it’s what e regime is doing.  The songs are usually good.

AAPL has a virtual monopoly in personal electronic device space.  However, AAPL is starting to piss me off with a horrible camera on iPhone 12 Pro as well as absolutely fucking hideously-difficult things like saving files/PDFs to the phone and some other stuff.

MSFT has a virtual monopoly in PC operating systems, business email, and other software.

GOOG has a virtual monopoly in search engine, personal email, and consumer video creation (YouTube has virtually no competition).  I would point out that Google search engine, however, is starting to show signs of being bad at performing certain searches.

The barriers to competition for all those companies is astronomically high and basically insurmountable.

Each has been and is presently so deeply ingrained in our lives, jobs, and society.  They all (more or less) make money by existing.

I don’t know anything about NVDA.

I held all those for a while at some point.  ICLN because of Biden's election, and CRSR, ARKG because they were bandwagon stocks.

Got burned by them, cut my losses, and rotated into other positions, and have been doing fine with some of the more boring but (usually) upward trending choices - VTI, MSFT, AAPL. Also loaded on what was a speculative position last year with higher conviction now - bought quite a few CRSP at what I believe to be the bottom at the 78 range - currently avg at 102+-.{Not even mentioning my stupid PLTR,BB position - gambles going wrong atm, believing in the hype and the reason I bought hasnt changed still hence why i havent sold}  
  
Although I have sizeable losses here these positions have elevated my positions amazingly.  
  
Holding a sizeable position with xxx% returns on AMD and NIO and very bullish on SE - recently added to my position at 280  
  
bought into the AMC hype with a 14 avg and sold of 80% at around the 60 mark  
  
  
  
Square shouldve been scalped and rebought 205-280 range and back is ridiculous but oh well  
  
sold JD into strenght to buy into my weaker positions - had a big position before. still bullish but seeing more upside elsewhere atm.  
  
I dont have any us mega caps- I know winners stay winners usually but I am looking for hopefully bigger returns albeith I run risk of big losses, clearly, as well - such as sizeble position in a clinical trial biotech AGTC - currently at a big loss aswell but that was expected. Lets see what happens here. stock at all time lows.  
  
  
  
for example although im sitting at a 10avg with my SKLZ position the downside is limited here imo, and potential huge hence why I have been adding to my position lately a lot bellow 10  
  
  
  
I do recommend people look into CPNG and let me know their thoughts. I am torn between adding to this position or keeping it small.

author: incognino123
body:
energnoc is the grandaddy of dr companies - think tesla or paypal if they never made any money.  enel is a big italian energy co and enel x is their bullshit attempt to be innovative.  DR is a pretty small space and since it has never really been economical it's mostly a space of "true believers" or energy weirdos.  Think rainman but for obscure tariff codes.  


And yeah Dana went to Dartmouth but generally folks are from the northeast.  They have started to pick up folks out west and elsewhere because of becoming remote and trying to expand their business.  But it's not that uncommon to see clusters of folks from a given background in startup environments. 


Voltus is not really a startup though.  Enernoc was bought and some folks didn't like the new culture and went their own way, it's more like a spin out of an existing business.  It's not disruptive **at all** and therefore deserves a not-disruptive multiple

author: solovino__
body:
Sell $NIO ASAP. Not a fan of $SNAP, but never dig into them enough to recommend selling. $MSFT and $META are good long term holds in my opinion. Gonna take a while to double your investment (assuming you bought today) but strong financially and bright future. 

$NIO is insanely overvalued. There’s no argument here. All EV and renewable stocks, wouldn’t suggest hopping in. P/Es are inflated so high it’s a guarantee we’ll see lower prices (a lot lower!) soon. History has shown.

I like undervalued gems. 

$SMCI, $ASO, $VIRT, $ERIC, and $MTZ are my small cap stocks for long term hold. Each have their reasons as to why I’m holding but more importantly, their financials are strong. P/S approximately 1 (tough to find this ratio in today’s market. Gotta dig.) P/E ratios are low relative to competitors. Some have little long term debt. Good ROEs. Increasing revenue. Just safe to hold and DCA down during times like this for me. 

Large cap stocks I’m holding long are $TMUS, $VZ, $AAPL, $V, $MA, and waiting for $PYPL to hit $130 to hop in. But guess what? If it doesn’t hit, I’m not jumping in. Simple as that. Plenty of stocks out there, no reason why you should jump in a stock that hasn’t convinced you yet.

Or if you don’t wanna bother and have a strong stomach to handle red days, buy $TQQQ. 

Last thing. Rule of thumb: if it’s being newly mentioned highly on Wall Street bets, and media outlets, most likely it’s too late.

author: SnipahShot
body:
I held MA for a really short amount of time and I own a MA card, but honestly, not sure about the long term future of these companies.

I have my bank's app which allows me to transfer money to others based on phone number and directly from my bank account. Last time I was at the dentist, I paid using that. Same as last time I purchased something from a website I am not familiar with, don't have to risk putting in my credit card number. 

I don't know what both V and MA doing in terms of innovation but NFC in credit cards is not safe either, they can be charged even while you are walking in the street. Pretty sure they can also be copied.

I don't really use my PayPal account but I think it would be a superior payment technology in the future than both credit card giants.

Maybe PYPL. But I’m not touching anything right now. 

I bought COST because when times are great, people go to Costco and buy big screens. When times are tough, people go to Costco and buy food and essentials. People always go to Costco to buy gas. 

Look at their stock history. It’s not volatile and essentially goes up. So I’m sticking with it for the long term. Costco isn’t going anywhere and will be here for the long term. I’m a believer and a customer, and the news is just noise.
